Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was finishing my lunch break at the construction site. It was Mark, someone I’d known since high school, his name flashing on the screen. I answered, and his voice was tight with worry—his car had broken down on a quiet road outside of town, and he needed someone to come help or at least keep him company until a tow truck arrived. I could hear the expectation in his voice, the unspoken rule that friends, even distant ones, show up when needed.

But as I hung up, I glanced at the notice board. The foreman had just posted about an optional safety training session next week. It wasn’t mandatory, but everyone knew that showing up meant you were serious about your job, about being part of the team. I’d been trying to prove myself, to show I was reliable and committed. If I skipped out, even for a good reason, it might look bad.

I felt the pressure building inside me—Mark’s need for help, the team’s silent expectations, my own desire to do right by both. I stood there, torn, the weight of both roles pressing down, unsure which way to turn.
